transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Thanks, everyone, for being here today.
So I'm Alex Van de Sand.
I am here to talk about mist.
But I do a little bit more than that on the foundation.
I'm an designer for the foundation.
And I do some other stuff like the website.
And I'm not sure if you ever look at the website, I suppose so.
But we do have some outrageous claims
on there, like buildings, top of the apps,
have a robot run your organization,
or how the internet was supposed to work.
Those are sort of outlandish claims.
And a few people got a little bit mad this year
that they were there.
And if you're one of those people, I'm sorry.
I'm kind of responsible because I wrote them.
I put them there.
And I'm here to explain what do we mean by that,
and why do we still stand for every word.
So what does that mean?
How the internet was supposed to work?
In order to understand this, let's see what the problem is.
The way that the internet works right now
is that if you're building a service,
you put up a server, a new server client.
And if you have five clients, then your server
will serve those five clients.
What happens if you have 500 or 500,000 clients?
Then that becomes a problem.
And there are normally two things that can happen.
The first one is that your server will just burn down
and crash.
And if you take with it a part of the internet history,
your users will be abandoned.
And if you were doing any sort of public good,
then that will be just lost.
So the second option that most people take
is the funding route, right?
Get some VC money, put a bunch of super servers out there,
and they will reach your 500,000 users.
But now, VCs are not donors.
So when they give you a million dollars,
they expect a billion dollars back somehow.
And since we don't have any, like,
easy currency on the internet right now,
the easiest, most accessible currency are eyeballs.
And also, by the way, we have all that private information
already on our servers, so let's just sell everything.
So advertisers.
And that's how we get where we are today, right?
Because all your users are just products
that you're selling to your shareholders
and your advertisers.
And it gets even weirder when you start seeing
the division of labor.
Because those big, big guys, they
are to serve you content.
They keep your private data.
They connect the users.
They solve any sort of conflicts.
And the other guys here, they just show you your stuff, which
is crazy because the computer you have on your pocket right now
is probably 1,000 or a million times more powerful
than the most powerful server when the web was created.
And I'm talking just about one device you have in your pocket.
Just imagine all the devices that are connected to you.
And it becomes even worse when you start thinking
about the ecosystem.
Because every one of those guys are separate islands.
They are silos.
And if you build your reputation on Airbnb,
then that reputation is locked to Airbnb.
You cannot take it elsewhere unless Airbnb wants it.
And if Facebook and YouTube doesn't want to work together,
they won't.
If it doesn't make sense for them to work together, they won't.
So that's the problem we see on the internet right now.
And the way it even really tries to solve it
is to distribute all the tasks.
So files are served by anyone in Swarm.
And your apps are all the apps that need consensus
are just run on every one of the full nodes.
And that's how we got it even where we are today.
And we launched this at DevCon Zero.
With just console, it's just very developer-oriented.
It's like the US era.
So before the US came along, whenever you wanted to build
a new software, you had also to build a new computer.
And the DOS came along.
And then now as a developer, you can build software
for all computers.
The same thing with the theorem tools, where now as a developer,
you can build blockchain apps just for--
you don't need to build your own blockchain for that.
But there is no graphic interface.
It requires the phone download.
And then in DevCon One, last year, we were talking,
and we launched the J-R-WALET.
And I think it's a great tool.
It's an advanced tool for specialists.
And I like to think of more like VisiCalk or Excel.
Also taking the personal computer example,
back then if you were an accountant,
if you wanted to do a spreadsheet,
you would take Excel or a VisiCalk.
And you didn't need to be a developer anymore.
But you still needed to be someone who
wanted to use specialized software.
Because what the WALET does is that it builds dynamic interfaces
for the contract that you want to interact with.
But still requires a full blockchain
and requires you to have it in order to use it.
And that's how we get to missed here at DevCon Two.
It's meant for the enthusiast users.
And by that, I want you to think Netscape Navigator or Firefox
in the sense that when they came, they weren't for everyone.
But they really help broaden the rhymes
of the types of users that were using the web back then.
And the idea is that we bring the full power of web interfaces
into smart contracts, or you could say vice versa.
And it has a light client, so it doesn't--
it won't require a full blockchain download.
And we are doing some creative ways of funding.
So let's look at how it looks.
So right here in the corner, we have the--
I launched a light client.
Right here, we have missed being launched.
And this is the recording unedited.
And what you can see there is it's
connecting for the first time.
So you choose the main network.
You can download your pre-sale wallet.
And then you create your password.
So missed will take you to the steps necessary
to create your account.
And once you create your account,
it will generate an identity account to you.
And you can start also funding it.
You can fund it with Bitcoin or any sort of other cryptocurrency.
And we are working with Coinbase.
At some point, you'll be able to fund it with a credit card.
And all you need to do is deposit.
And all meanwhile, while you're doing this,
it's already downloading.
It's downloading already more than half of the whole chain.
And if you still-- if you-- it's still not enough,
we can offer you a little bit of reading material
so you can try to understand more about each year
and on the meantime.
So for example, we can let's learn
about how to build a democracy on the blockchain.
I love this phrase over there, which is,
on the blockchain, no one knows you are a fridge.
But we don't have time to read this.
I'm not going to talk about dows right now
or democracy on the blockchain.
So you close it, and it's there.
It's launched.
It has already synced.
So in less than one minute and 30 second--
and of course, it will depend on some other factors--
we were able to sync from scratch in a clean machine,
and you can start using Ethereum right now.
And that's the main ad.
And I want now to switch to the test
net to show you some other very cool stuff.
So this is the Ethereum wallet.
I think both of you have used it at some point.
It's really meant to help you use smart contracts.
So I created a smart contract that is called Donut Coins,
which is just a token that you send around.
And I want to send five Donut Coins to a friend.
Now, here's something cool, right?
Because right now, Ethereum has the two address,
the firm address, and a few information like bytecode.
And that doesn't really communicate anything to the user.
What we are doing right now is that we
are able to decode whatever that bytecode means
and show the user exactly what the transaction he's about to do
is supposed to do at least.
So it's a transfer function.
It's going to transfer to that green guy on the bottom,
and it's going to transfer five.
Five what?
Five Donut Coins.
Those are the parameters.
And of course, if you want to check the contract,
you can always click on the top to check the actual source code
of the contract.
But you're not doing that right now.
So all we need to do is you just check if the parameters
are right, type or password on your gun.
And I think that's a great way of interfacing
with smart contracts.
But here's the nice trick.
All this wallet we've built, it's built in pure HTML and CSS.
And anyone should be able to create another wallet
with as such a rich interface as this.
And that's what we want miss to do.
So in the left here, we have a browser button
where you can just browse to any app you want.
And we have so many apps already and more are being built.
And you could just type any address on the top.
But here, you cannot really see it.
But in the top, I'm not pasting an address.
I'm pasting a hash.
So what does the hash means?
A hash is not a location where you find an application.
A hash really describes a specific version of an application.
It's a bunch of files, a specific version
of a bunch of images, a bunch of HTML, a bunch of JavaScript.
And when you paste a hash there, what it does,
it's connecting you to Swarm.
And that's also recording of a live prototype.
And you can see busy Z up there.
And what it's doing is that it's just downloaded
this whole interface from Swarm, meaning that it's now
running on your local machine.
And now, since it's running on a local machine,
it doesn't necessarily know about you.
And then the first thing you have to do is kind of authenticate
yourself.
But instead of the apps requiring to have every app you go,
you have to create a username and a password.
And that's depending on the central server that can be hacked.
Instead, MIST provides you with a few accounts
that you can just choose.
So I want to identify myself to this voting app
with that second account over there.
And once you authorize it, your app
can kind of change the interface to reflect that now it
knows that you are this given account.
And now I created this little app.
It's just a voting, a stake voting thing.
You can just-- you put a parameter there,
like say something, let's say Game of Thrones
is better than Star Wars.
And anyone can vote to agree or disagree,
and their vote to be counted in stake voting.
And here's the magic, right?
I created all this whole interface.
And the whole purpose of it was just to get to this point
where I create you a transaction.
And once you create that transaction,
now the user is back in control.
Because the user can see all the parameters,
he can see that he's about to do a vote application.
He's doing a vote on that account on the top.
And he's using a first parameter is a hash of whatever he said.
The first is just a yes or no, meaning he agree or disagrees.
And in order to vote, all he needs to do is type his password.
So he's back in control.
So think about this, right?
I just run this whole app, and it runs completely
without servers.
Because all the files you need to run them
are where downloaded via swarm from a peer to peer network
and that are locally on your machine.
All your private information, your log in,
your account information is kept by you,
by your computer that is safe.
And finally, all the information that you need to be public,
to be common, to be synchronized, is kept on the blockchain.
And you can see that, well, it seems that everyone agrees with me.
And I think that's the kind of architecture
that we want to move moving forward all the depth
to think about, an architecture where all the private information
is kept and managed by the user himself.
And there is no central server.
Anyone that goes to that particular depth
will always find this exact version of the application.
And what are their next steps that we want?
So the next step here is, first of all,
hashes are terrible user interfaces
because they are long, they are not human friendly,
and they are not updatable.
So you can just replace them for the ENS system
that Nick was talking yesterday.
Also, we have a Solidity and now has authenticated contracts
which allow some nice things with swarm.
And right now, the way we are doing this decoding thing
is that we just download a bunch of signatures
with myths when you download myths.
And if it's not enough, you can ping a central server.
But with authenticated contracts, what you can do
is that once you interact with a contract,
we can download both the source code and the API directly
from swarm and show you exactly what it's about to do.
Another very cool thing that we are working on
is easier in Solers.
We already have DMGs, we already have windows in Solers
and the latest releases.
We are starting to do signing with PGP.
And we want to do a full app signing
so we can eventually be on App Stores too.
And there's another interesting thing.
It's not.
Right now, I think most people underestimate
how much how users come into ecosystem
affects how users think.
Because everyone who has to come into the ecosystem
has to have bot each in an exchange at some point.
So a lot of users are get in with this trading idea.
Back in the beginning, we could allow mining where anyone could
just use their computers to get iter that long past gone.
But what swarm allows us to do is that by just sharing
your internet connection, you could get a little bit of iter.
If you have a file that just suddenly becomes popular
because everyone is using that application,
you will be paid a tiny amount of iters, which is not a big amount,
but enough so you can start playing around with smart contracts
without having to buy in the next change.
Another thing we are excited to be working on
is sloppable backends.
Gef is a great node, but there are some other people
doing some very nice work.
And Parity basically saved our assets
in the beginning of this week.
So we are trying to work with every--
with the other developers to see what do we
need to make sloppable backends where the user can just
select another node and it would download it live.
And you just-- a single file would have all the configuration
necessarys to work-- for miss to work with any back-end
that you want.
Now, another thing we have on the roadmap, right?
And we have tons of things that you
want to talk about.
We don't have time for them.
But so first of all, each year in RCC67 is a very cool thing
I want to work with.
It's an idea to create a single link
that you can-- it will definitely make creating smart contracts
a lot easier because instead of having
to download a JavaScript library and creating
a transaction out of JavaScript, you
could create a new transaction by just clicking on it.
So you would click on it.
The link would come with a URI saying
the whose address is it's going to.
What are the parameters?
And then just by having static files,
we've fixed a link anyone could create a file, a link
that you would open missed with the right way
to do a transaction.
Invitation files.
We saw in the beginning that the first thing you do on the wallet
is download your pre-sale wallet.
Of course, fewer and fewer people still have pre-sale wallets.
But what if you could use that same mechanism
to create some sort of invitation system,
where I can create a new, a tiny little wallet
with a small amount of data and give to a friend
that will-- from his point of view,
it just looks like an invitation file that
allows him to be a part of Ethereum.
He drags it.
And then it already has-- it already
has some parameters, some functions,
and things that allow him to connect back to your friends.
We want to work with the deterministic in paper wallets.
And we are moving the account management
from the node to the client.
It has two big advantages.
One of them, it makes the node slappable back ends easier,
because now your node only needs to be
able to think of the blockchain.
It doesn't need to actually do the account management.
And the user doesn't need to have new accounts for every node.
They want it easier for them to switch.
And also allows us to do more extensible things,
like at some point, allowing you to do anything you want
to do with an account.
You could do with a contract, let's say.
You could do with a multi-sig.
Or you could do with a scheduler contract,
or anything like that.
And there's another thing.
And the reason I chose that picture
is it's something I want to leave you guys with.
I come from Brazil.
And in Brazil, there's literally nothing that's
more than 500 years old, and mostly nothing that's
more than 200 years old.
But here is different.
In China and in Europe, we still can find roads
that are thousands of years old.
Those are roads that are built by empire
that have long been gone.
And that after those empires, other kingdoms have come and gone.
And the roads are still there.
And the roads are still usable.
And they are not usable because they were magical,
or they are built very well in the beginning.
They are still usable today because those people that
came after the original purpose of the road was gone,
those people could just do their own road maintenance.
Now, railroads are not like that.
You can find railroads that are 30 years old
that because a single company has gone bankrupt,
or because the government just lost interest on that,
it just lies there abandoned, and nobody else can do it,
can keep using it.
So let's try to build the internet like we build roads,
not railroads.
Think of Twitter, think of WeChat,
think of all those apps that we use every day
that make a big difference.
They can now simply go away tomorrow
if they are blocked by a government,
or if their board makes a bad decision that takes the app
in a different direction than the community is.
Let's try to build apps that allow,
that just like roads, we will allow anyone who is,
the community that allows the app to keep be alive
and keep running long after the original purpose
and the original creators of them are gone.
Apps that other communities can take over, can control,
and can take forward.
Apps that are truly unstoppable,
and are truly there for a long time,
and they are for the long term.
And I would really like to thank my whole team
for all the good work that they've been doing,
and a lot of other people are not directly part of my team,
but are also a very important step
into having missed where it is today.
Thank you.
